德国最大的房东 Vonovia 的老板罗尔夫·布赫 (Rolf Buch) 警告说： “我们正在将我们的建筑业推向深渊。”困扰德国建筑商的危机远非该国唯一的经济问题。但这一问题尤其严重，涉及占GDP 12%、雇用 100 万建筑工人的行业。这对于德国经济及其社会的健康至关重要。

政府承诺在 2021 年上台时每年建造 40 万套公寓。行业团体估计，每年需要建造 70 万套左右的公寓，尤其是为逃离饱受战争蹂躏的国家的超过 100 万乌克兰人提供住房。无论真实数字是多少，每个人都同意去年建造的 295,000 座并没有减少这一数字。布赫先生称该国部分地区经济适用房短缺是“社会火药桶”。

今年这个数字可能会更低。由于供应链中断（其中一些与战争有关），材料和能源的价格飙升。与此同时，较高的利率增加了许多德国建筑商赖以启动项目的债务成本。结果，建筑公司和房地产开发商纷纷破产。今年前四个月，有 437 家建筑公司申请破产，与 2022 年同期相比增加了 20%。上个月，Gerch 和 Development Partner、杜塞尔多夫的两家开发商、纽伦堡的 Project Immobilien 和慕尼黑的 Euroboden 破产了向上。

“这不是一个正常运转的市场，”智囊团 Ifo 负责人克莱门斯·福斯特 (Clemens Fuest) 表示。他说，原因是繁文缛节。 2015年，德国在大城市的热门地区实行“租金制动”，将新租赁价格限制在特定地点租金指数确定的水平之上不超过10%。尽管理论上排除了新建筑，但该政策仍然阻碍了最需要的地方的住房开发。此外，Fuest 先生表示，租户受到法律的良好保护，这对行业来说是进一步的负担。

其他规则使得建筑成本变得越来越高。已经很严格的环境法规将变得更加严格。如果按照计划于 2025 年 1 月 1 日推出名为eh- 40 的新隔热标准，建筑成本将增加 20%，而过去几年建筑成本已增加了三分之二。 BFW是一个由独立房地产和住房公司组成的联邦协会。 “我们拥有世界上最好的防火和隔音法规，”他补充道。他的意思并不完全是一种恭维：他感叹，所有这些世界一流的监管正在扼杀整个行业。

德国建筑行业联合会 Bauindustrie 负责人蒂姆-奥利弗·穆勒 (Tim-Oliver Müller) 指出了其他令人头痛的官僚主义问题。申请建筑许可证需要向当局提交八份纸质副本。联邦共和国的 16 个州都有不同的建筑规则。各个城市，甚至全国近 11,000 个公社中的一些，都有自己的限制。每当应用程序发现故障时，无论故障有多小，处理该故障的时钟都会重置。穆勒先生建议所有申请都应该是数字化的，如果当局在三个月内没有对申请做出回应，那么申请应该会自动获得批准。

9 月 25 日，德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨 (Olaf Scholz) 将主持一场由 60 名政治家、商界领袖和民间社会代表参加的峰会。在柏林附近梅塞贝格城堡的一次仪式上，他的内阁最近通过了减轻企业税负的措施，包括建筑商磨损扣除的新规定。行业人士表示，这还远远不够。他们要求放宽建筑的绿色规则、更多的税收减免以及帮助解决高额借贷成本。如果政府不采取行动，深渊就会来临。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 14:20:20 GMT /内容/thf7n19kdeg8vtfeg1qfniepdu42gatn https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/07/german-builders-are-on-the-brink-of-collapse TikTok is wading into South-East Asia’s e-commerce wars

今年3 月，TikTok首席执行官寿子周 (Shou Zi Chew) 在华盛顿面对愤怒的议员，议员们对他进行了五个小时的盘问，话题涵盖错误信息和心理健康等。在短视频应用程序最大的市场美国，禁令的威胁迫在眉睫。其他西方政府也发出了类似的声音。 TikTok 由一家名为字节跳动的中国公司拥有，自 2020 年以来，该公司已以国家安全为由被排除在另一个大市场印度之外。

与周先生六​​月份在雅加达受到的欢迎形成鲜明对比。他在印度尼西亚首都吸引了包括政府官员在内的人群，他的公司在东南亚的计划，承诺未来几年将在该地区投资“数十亿美元”。由于全球其他地区的前景充满不确定性，TikTok 于 2020 年将全球总部迁至新加坡，并着眼于东南亚近 7 亿消费者，以巩固其财富。除了该地区的数字企业之外，人们对他的演讲的反应从赞成到热烈不等。

这是因为 TikTok 在东南亚的野心不仅仅是愚蠢的舞蹈视频。 2021 年，它推出了 TikTok Shop，让用户可以直接从应用程序购买产品。新加坡研究公司 Momentum Works 表示，去年在其平台上向全球销售了价值约 50 亿美元的产品。今年的目标是 200 亿美元，其中四分之三来自东南亚。

这次进军电子商务正值该地区该行业的动荡时期。 Shopee 占东南亚去年约 1000 亿美元在线商品销售总额的近一半（见图 1），该公司报告其平台销售额连续两个季度下降。其新加坡母公司 Sea Group 的市值仅为 2021 年 10 月达到的 2000 亿美元的十分之一。Sea 已裁员，撤出东南亚以外的业务，并于 8 月告诉投资者要做好亏损准备。面对日益激烈的竞争，它会增加支出。 Lazada 是一家总部位于新加坡的电子商务平台，可能从未实现过盈利，但多年来已迎来第五任首席执行官。今年三月，其中国母公司阿里巴巴分拆为六家公司，引发了更多骚动。

TikTok 能否利用竞争对手的麻烦？该应用程序看起来确实非常适合东南亚的在线购物习惯。它在该地区已经拥有超过 3 亿用户。咨询公司贝恩和拥有 Facebook 和 Instagram 的 Meta 进行的一项研究发现，近一半的消费者在网上购物时使用社交媒体，尤其是短视频和消息应用程序来查找产品。投资公司海登资本 (Hayden Capital) 的 Fred Liu 指出，正如在“社交商务”发源地中国一样，对于那些“移动优先”的购物者来说，娱乐和商业之间的界限变得模糊。为了减少对直播产品评论的依赖，TikTok 正在其应用程序中测试一个市场选项卡，该选项卡允许卖家在平台上列出他们的商品，而无需付费给有影响力的人在他们的视频中插入产品。

不过，目前还不要将地区现有企业排除在外。 TikTok Shop 的商品以最适合宣传视频和冲动购买的商品为主，例如衣服和化妆品，而其竞争对手则提供更广泛的商品种类，从小玩意到家具。 Momentum Works 的 Vion Yau 估计，TikTok 上的平均订单价值约为 5 美元，而 Shopee 的平均订单价值为 8 美元，Lazada 的平均订单价值为 10 美元。

Shopee、Lazada 和另一家本土巨头 Tokopedia 也建立了自己的物流网络和支付系统，以避开东南亚棘手的半岛和群岛地理以及往往简陋的基础设施。这使得这些公司的运营效率比 TikTok 更高，后者依赖外部供应商来存储和运输其产品，从而减少了对购物体验的控制并侵蚀了利润。尽管东南亚人使用 TikTok 等社交媒体应用程序来发现新产品，但他们在那里购买的可能性较小。根据贝恩和 Meta 的报告，超过一半的购物者在销售时转向老式电子商务网站，受到更好的质量和更快的交货时间的吸引。

TikTok 可能会克服这些障碍。由于其中国母公司 2200 亿美元的估值，它的财力比大多数公司都雄厚。但 Shopee 的紧缩开支为 Sea 提供了现金缓冲来捍卫自己的地盘。 Lazada 7 月份获得阿里巴巴 8.45 亿美元注资。本土企业并不是 TikTok 的唯一竞争对手。上个月，中国另一家大型电子商务公司拼多多的分支机构特木悄然在菲律宾推出了在线商店。争夺东南亚在线购物者的战斗才刚刚开始。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 14:20:20 GMT /内容/i75p9u72mg8gj4pffnma84qtaqv5frr7 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/07/tiktok-is-wading-into-south-east-asias-e-commerce-wars Trade unions take on more American firms—and not just in America

过去四十年来，美国老板们已经习惯了劳工骚乱。 1981年，罗纳德·里根当选总统后不久，解雇了数千名罢工的空中交通管制员（尽管他曾经领导过好莱坞演员工会），自此以来，美国工会一直相对温和。从 2000 年到 2022 年，美国平均每年经历 17 次大型停工（影响 1,000 名工人或更多），低于 1977 年至 1999 年期间的每年 84 次。工会会员人数已从 1979 年 2000 万的峰值下降到去年的 1400 万多一点。 ，在公共部门和私营部门之间平分。如今，只有 6% 的私营部门工人加入了工会，而 20 世纪 70 年代这一比例超过 20%。

今年，就业市场紧张、技术变革加速（想想 Chat GPT ）以及公众对工会支持率的上升（根据民意调查机构盖洛普的数据，工会在美国人中的支持率达到创纪录的 67%），这些因素共同鼓舞了工人。罢工正在激增。今年前 7 个月，该国已出现 16 家大片，高于 2022 年同期的 11 家，也是 2005 年以来最多的。好莱坞编剧和演员与制片厂陷入长达数月的对峙。 8 月 30 日，99.5% 的美国航空空乘工会投票决定继续罢工。底特律大型汽车制造商的工人威胁要效仿。

如果这对美国老板来说还不够令人烦恼的话，他们的一些企业在海外也感受到了痛苦。 9 月 8 日，雪佛龙在澳大利亚的两家液化天然气 ( LNG ) 工厂的工人可能停工。他们每天会停工长达 11 个小时，如果不能就工资达成一致，就会升级为全面罢工。代表雪佛龙澳大利亚工人的工会离岸联盟最近拒绝了这家能源巨头的薪酬提议，声称这些提议比其二流竞争对手提供的薪酬更为吝啬。

雪佛龙知道如何遏制罢工行动。去年，加州炼油厂的工会工人屈服并结束了为期十周的罢工，但没有获得更高的工资。北方夏末天然气需求较低，这可能会削弱海上联盟的议价地位。

然而，长期的争端可能会给这家美国能源巨头带来麻烦。去年，高更 (Gorgon) 和惠斯通 (Wheatstone) 这两家澳大利亚工厂总共为其所有者带来了近 70 亿美元的净利润，为其净利润贡献了近五分之一。此外，雪佛龙在澳大利亚生产的近90%的液化天然气都是根据长期合同出售的，它宁愿不食言。雪佛龙在美国的老板们明白这一点。太平洋彼岸的工人也是如此。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 14:20:20 GMT /内容/q6pu9dg0avdqdtm1di7gco9cqdkm8r7j https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/07/trade-unions-take-on-more-american-firms-and-not-just-in-america Meet the world’s most enduring product

公司可以长久生存，但他们的产品通常是短暂的。苹果公司可能是世界上最有价值的企业，但为其成功奠定了早期基础的 Apple II 电脑和初代 Mac 却存放在博物馆中（如果有的话）。苹果的智能手机竞争对手三星是从销售面条起家的。福特最新的F -150 Lightning 电动皮卡除了四个轮子外，与T型车几乎没有什么共同之处。在技​​术、商业模式和消费者品味不断发展的世界中，“如果它没有坏，就不要修理它”这句格言毫无意义。

除非，也就是说，你是皇家恩菲尔德。 1932 年，这家总部位于英国的摩托车制造商推出了 Bullet。 91 年后，这家自 1994 年起就由印度人掌管的公司推出了这款标志性两轮车的最新版本。它看起来与原版几乎一模一样。

该公司坚称，对发动机（马力仅为原版的三分之二）、底盘和座椅进行了改动。然而，除了缺少启动（这引起了粉丝的一些抱怨）和增加的燃油表（没有引起任何评论）之外，这些都是不引人注目的。其他 21 世纪摩托车上常见的功能（例如转速表或温度计）均不存在，更不用说针对不同条件的计算机辅助骑行模式了。正如一位 YouTuber 所说，这种骑行体验和“排气管发出的甜美嘎​​吱声”可能与 20 世纪 30 年代的情况大致相同。

这使得 Bullet 成为连续生产中最不变的车辆，也是有史以来最不变的产品之一（ AK -47 步枪问世只有 75 年）。在印度，它也是一种商业和文化现象。它的销量仍然超过皇家恩菲尔德的大部分其他产品，包括更现代的设计。 6 月份早期版本的销量超过 8,000 件。印度道路上的总人数很难估计​​，但几乎可以肯定有数百万。很少有物品能引起如此程度的喜爱——不仅仅是来自该国的摩托车爱好者。

至少有 1,200 个专门的马术俱乐部。在旁遮普邦的田野里，在拉达克危险的山坡上，可以看到覆盖着锈迹斑斑的标本，在城市街道上躲避牛和汽车。对于宝莱坞英雄和恶棍来说，它都是不可或缺的装备。印度武装部队于 1949 年订购了 500 辆两轮车用于该国北部边境巡逻，首次引发了印度“子弹”热潮，该部队拥有一支专门驾驶“子弹”的特技团队。 2017 年，龙卷风队（该队的名字）完成了用一辆摩托车载运 58 人的壮举。

所有这些，再加上这些机器似乎永远不会过期，并且几乎任何人都可以在任何地方修理，这解释了 Bullet 经久不衰的受欢迎程度。对于许多难以想象拥有一套房子甚至一辆汽车的印度人来说，Bullet 不仅令人向往，而且每辆 2,400 美元的价格几乎是可以买到的。既然吸引力如此不变，谁还需要改变呢？ ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 14:20:20 GMT /内容/6flkt73o13b0pbqru5rhdohfochaikaf https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/07/meet-the-worlds-most-enduring-product Networking for introverts: a how-to guide

企业生活会出现一些压力很大的时刻。给你的老板带来坏消息；面对面试小组；做一个大演讲。但如果你是一个内向的人，没有什么比社交更糟糕的了。

您到达一个活动现场，发现那里的每个人显然都已经互相认识了。然后你更仔细地观察并发现其他受苦者。他们是真正阅读会议简介的人。他们在手机上查看电子邮件的强度比在办公室时更大。它们在房间里无休无止地循环，就像海洋中的塑料碎片等待着被什么东西钩住。他们在主厅就座，而音响工程师仍在测试麦克风。

幸运的是，有一些关于如何与陌生人打破僵局的建议。不幸的是，它很糟糕。一位圣人建议在队列中进行联系，因为与你前面和后面的人交谈更容易。你的目的是在自动扶梯、厕所和队列中伏击人们，以获取你的名牌。在排队喝咖啡的时候，说出六个难以理解的词来打开工作和销售的大门：“为重要的主题演讲加油？”

继续。不要害怕笑，因为没有什么比一个不停地笑的人更能消除房间里的紧张气氛了。将个人信息带入对话中，以免人们认为您只是为了商业利益而参加财务管理软件会议。使用对方的名字两次，以表现出真正的参与。并在事后记录对话，以便您可以跟进。

将这些成分加在一起，您就拥有了成功的秘诀：

“为重要的主题演讲做准备吗？”

“什么？”

“为重要的主题演讲做准备吗？”

“我不知道这意味着什么。”

[扫描名牌]“基思，是吗？”

“呃，是的。”

[笑]“我要生孩子了，基思。”

“基思？”

[拿出记事本]

如果这就是怎么联网，难怪人们早早就去大殿了。

在 LinkedIn 这样的网站上建立联系的压力要小得多。毕竟，没有眼神交流，而且交通规则也是商定的。所有这些联系请求似乎确实对职业生涯有所帮助。 LinkedIn 的 Karthik Rajkumar 和来自学术界的合著者去年发表的一篇论文发现了支持各种网络的洞察力的实证证据，因为它们为您带来了新信息、更罕见和疏远的关系（或“弱关系”）比密切接触者更有用。

研究人员随机改变了LinkedIn向用户展示的“你可能认识的人”推荐算法，因此网站上的人们之间较弱和较强的联系的普遍程度有所不同。实验表明，与拥有 25 个或更多共同朋友的关系相比，较弱的关系（例如，一对用户只有一个共同朋友）更有可能导致工作申请和工作调动。

对于内向的人来说，这听起来像是涅槃：开始向每个人发送连接请求的垃圾邮件，关上办公室的门，等待工作机会。但这并不那么容易。即使是较弱的关系也需要照顾。即使在网上，如果您发现充满活力，与人互动也会更容易；奥古斯塔纳学院的乔安娜·戴维斯 (Joanna Davis) 及其合著者对 LinkedIn 进行的一项基于调查的研究发现，外向性是社交能力的预测因素。

对于内向的人来说，没有一种真正轻松的社交方式。尽管如此，还是有一些方法比排队等候并希望不知道如何从机器中取出咖啡的人是你职业成功的门票更明智。

真正的秘密是把你的精力留给你最可能感兴趣的人。例如，在网络领域，拉吉库马尔博士的研究并没有发现关系越弱越好。在LinkedIn上建立人际网络的最佳点是与你关系较弱的人：与只有一个共同朋友的人相比，与有十个共同朋友的人建立联系会显着增加换工作的可能性。

换句话说，如果你能找到那些可以给你带来新信息、但又足够接近你的世界、使这些信息有用的人，那么网络就会得到回报。在离线世界中，像 Chat GPT这样的工具应该可以让您更轻松地在活动参与者列表中找到有用的潜在客户。但你仍然需要克服所有的本能并接近它们。 ■

; Thu, 07 Sep 2023 14:20:20 GMT /内容/575u2odq91cnb2tplcv097j7m5l29in8 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/07/networking-for-introverts-a-how-to-guide America’s bosses just won’t quit. That could spell trouble

在首席执行官们脑海中盘旋的众多担忧中，没有什么比继任问题更令人不安的了。许多老板辛苦地爬到公司的最高层后，很难想象放弃控制权并将自己的遗产交到另一个人的手中。

相反，越来越多的美国老板选择完全推迟此事。数据提供商 MyLog IQ 的数据显示，截至去年底，已有 101 名标准普尔500 强公司首席执行官担任高管职位超过 10 年，而十年前这一数字仅为 36 名。尽管有些人，比如任职时间最长的沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren巴菲特)，在职时间长达 53 年，创办了自己经营的公司，但大多数人都是雇佣工人。摩根大通银行的杰米·戴蒙 (Jamie Dimon )、软件公司 Adob​​e 的尚塔努·纳拉延 (Shantanu Narayen) 以及特许酒店希尔顿酒店的克里斯·纳塞塔 (Chris Nassetta) 都是比他们的前辈更长寿的人之一。在过去的十年里，这些长期任职的首席执行官将标准普尔500 强企业的平均任期从六年延长到了七年。

一些老板因不愿继续前进而臭名昭著。今年早些时候，霍华德·舒尔茨结束了他作为咖啡连锁店星巴克老板的第三次任期。去年年底，鲍勃·艾格 (Bob Iger) 从他选定的继任者鲍勃·查佩克 (Bob Chapek) 手中夺回了媒体巨头迪士尼的控制权。 7 月，他的两年合同延长至 2026 年底。继任问题长期以来一直困扰着巴菲特的伯克希尔哈撒韦公司。

当然，很多公司的高管都在附近徘徊，为他们提供良好的服务。随着人们健康状况持续时间的延长，一旦老板达到任意退休年龄就强迫他们离职（许多公司仍然这样做）是没有必要的。然而，美国商界领袖任期的延长却令人担忧。

1991 年，当时就读于哥伦比亚商学院的唐纳德·汉布里克 (Donald Hambrick) 和格雷戈里·福富富 (Gregory Fukutomi) 发表了一篇关于首席执行官任期“季节”的颇具影响力的论文。他们认为，在最初的几年里，随着老板掌握了诀窍，绩效会提高，但后来随着他们变得更加抵制变革和减少对工作的投入，绩效会下降。波士顿大学的弗朗索瓦·布罗切特 (Francois Brochet) 及其合著者在 2015 年发表的一篇论文试图通过研究美国上市公司的市场价值与首席执行官任期之间的关系来量化这一临界点。他们发现，在工作的头十年左右，绩效有所上升，然后趋于平缓，然后在大约 15 年后开始下降。

“最终你会失去活力和创造力，”曾经经营医疗技术公司美敦力（Medtronic）、现在在哈佛商学院任教的比尔·乔治（Bill George）说道。当公司需要重塑时，这种活力尤其重要。微软在萨提亚·纳德拉 (Satya Nadella) 的领导下转型为人工智能先锋的云计算巨头，如果史蒂夫·鲍尔默 (Steve Ballmer) 一直坚持下去，他带领微软公司度过了 2000 年至 2014 年的停滞期，那么微软可能永远不会实现这一转变。

即使一位首席执行官的长期任职似乎因出色的表现而合理，但延长任期也会带来风险。艾格在担任迪士尼老板的最初 15 年期间曾三次推迟退休，导致许多潜在的继任者到其他地方碰碰运气。猎头公司 Spencer Stuart 的贾森·鲍姆加滕 (Jason Baumgarten) 指出，等待寻找经验与现任首席执行官相当的替代首席执行官的董事会必然会发现，拖延的时间越长，就越难。

咨询公司毕马威 (KPMG)的克劳迪娅·艾伦 (Claudia Allen) 表示，理想情况下，继任计划应该从首席执行官就任之日就开始。这包括建立候选人渠道、评估他们的技能并制定填补空白的计划。最好避免出现像通用电气（曾经强大的美国工业巨头）取代杰克韦尔奇的六年传奇事件。将首席执行官和董事会主席的角色分开也会有所帮助（任命一位首席独立董事很少足以限制兼任这两项职务的全能老板，更不用说解雇其中一位了）。标准普尔500 强公司的首席执行官中，任职时间超过 10 年的三分之二的人同时担任董事会主席，而整个集团的首席执行官则为五分之二。

也许继任最重要的规则就是彻底决裂。轮流结束后还留下来的老板会给他们的继任者带来伤害。最有害的例子是首席执行官继续担任“执行董事长”，这是一个定义松散的头衔，赋予其持有者干涉重大决策的权利，同时逃避运营责任。摩根士丹利 (Morgan Stanley) 的詹姆斯·戈尔曼 (James Gorman) 将在未来几个月辞去该行首席执行官职务后接任这一头衔。

去年，15%的标准普尔500强公司由执行董事长担任主席。杰夫·贝索斯和鲁珀特·默多克等一些创始人渴望在自己创办的公司中保持发言权。对于其他人来说，这个角色可能看起来是平滑过渡的便捷方式。但它带来了危险。前任可能很难接受战略的转变，并且对于谁最终负责可能会出现混乱。在艾格担任迪士尼执行董事长期间，他和查佩克在一些重大决策上发生了冲突，削弱了这位新人的可信度。

获得来世

首席执行官们发现很难放手，这并不奇怪，这不仅是因为权力具有诱惑力。乔治表示，许多人都觉得自己在达到职业顶峰后却无事可做。他建议老板们寻找利用自己智慧的方法，而不是退休后过上悠闲的生活。有些人可能会选择担任董事会成员。其他人，比如他，可能会教书。其他人仍然可能尝试涉足政治。在最近一次重返星巴克之前，舒尔茨曾考虑过竞选总统。一些人敦促戴蒙先生追求一项。接受你领导的组织在没有你的情况下仍能生存是令人不舒服的。但下台并不意味着默默无闻。许多美国老板仍然有很多可以给予的——尤其是为下一代提供机会。 ■

; Mon, 04 Sep 2023 17:11:00 GMT /内容/ce87186kijsdbf3i8fqm1h3n5nfgsunn https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/04/americas-bosses-just-wont-quit-that-c​​ould-spell-trouble Meet Ernie, China’s answer to ChatGPT

埃尼·博特对科学有一些有争议的观点。 8月31日向公众发布的中国领先的人工智能（ AI ）聊天机器人认为，covid-19起源于2019年7月的美国电子烟用户；同年晚些时候，该病毒通过美国龙虾传播到中国武汉市。相比之下，在政治问题上，聊天机器人却相当安静。厄尼对“谁是中国国家主席？”等问题感到困惑。会告诉你习近平母亲的名字，但不会告诉你他兄弟姐妹的名字。如果问及社会主义的弊端，它会一片空白。它经常试图通过说：“让我们谈谈别的事情吧。”来转移敏感的对话。

对于熟悉受到严格审查的互联网的中国用户来说，厄尼的沉默并不奇怪。他们可能对聊天机器人的起源更感到惊讶。对于厄尼来说，这是中国科技巨头百度的创意，多年来一直被竞争对手超越。现在，多亏了人工智能，该公司正在卷土重来。它的成功程度将在很大程度上说明 中国科技产业的前景，中国科技产业一方面受到美国出口管制的挤压，另一方面又受到习近平日益加强的独裁主义的挤压。

十年前，百度作为中国最大搜索引擎的运营商，处于中国互联网的中心。它与中国最有价值的两家互联网公司阿里巴巴和腾讯一起组成了“ BAT ”三巨头。由于外国搜索引擎在中国被禁止或受到严格审查，它的核心业务几乎没有面临竞争。

百度从未失去其在中文搜索领域的主导地位；目前仍占有全国90%以上的搜索流量。然而，技术格局的变化给该公司留下了昔日的阴影。现在，大多数中国互联网用户在腾讯微信等超级应用程序的帮助下上网。广告收入已转移到抖音（TikTok 的中国表亲）等应用程序上。配送平台美团和电子商务公司拼多多的市值已超过百度 500 亿美元。为了效仿，它推出了自己的送货和购物服务，以及支付和社交媒体等其他服务。这些大多都失败了。该公司的市值现在相当于腾讯的八分之一，低于五年前的五分之一（见图表）。

然而，百度人工智能的推出重新点燃了人们对该公司的兴奋之情。 Ernie 在发布后 19 小时内下载量就达到了 100 万次（据其美国制造商 Open AI称，Chat GPT在五天后就达到了 100 万次下载）。随着分析师、投资者和普通民众对这款机器人的质疑不断，百度股价在发布当天上涨了 4% 以上。尽管包括面部识别公司商汤科技在内的其他四家公司在同一天推出了类似的服务，并且另外六家公司已获得中国政府的批准，但厄尼引起了最多的关注。

上个月，百度首席执行官兼联合创始人李彦宏表示，人工智能的推出对公司来说是一次“范式转变”。然而，这种转变并不是一夜之间发生的。经过多年的投资，百度已成为中国最先进的人工智能公司之一，其系统涵盖芯片设计、深度学习框架以及专有的人工智能模型和应用程序。该公司于 2019 年开始构建 Ernie，使其成为最早尝试此类“生成式”人工智能的公司之一。

到目前为止，百度一直回避就这项技术对其利润意味着什么提供明确的指导，但分析师认为，厄尼将为其搜索引擎和其他服务带来更多流量，从而提高广告收入。百度还巩固了自己作为中国最大人工智能云提供商的地位，并开始为希望根据其特定需求定制人工智能模型的公司提供定制服务。

对于百度进军人工智能领域的另一项重要举措—— 自动驾驶出租车业务，人们的热情却较为冷淡。该服务已在中国的一些城市推出，允许用户通过移动应用程序呼叫机器人出租车。但出行仍必须进行远程监控，而且更广泛的推广可能还需要数年时间。很少有分析师预计该部门很快就会产生可观的利润。

Much of what comes next for Baidu will depend on policymaking in Beijing and Washington. Restrictions on the sale of advanced semiconductors to China imposed by President Joe Biden's administration are causing the company a world of pain. Almost all of those chips, which most AI builders use to train their models, are produced outside China. Using a larger quantity of lower-powered processors is possible, but expensive.

In Baidu's case, its AI efforts rely on the Kunlunxin chip. Although it designed the chip itself, production is outsourced to companies like TSMC , a Taiwanese contract manufacturer . America's restrictions put limits on the types of chip that foreign foundries can sell to Chinese firms, and no domestic supplier has been able to produce such advanced components. Since America's restrictions were announced, Baidu has been downplaying the importance of the Kunlunxins, which may hint that it is having problems procuring them.

China is trying to catch up in the manufacture of advanced chips. On August 29th Huawei, a maker of telecoms-gear clobbered by American sanctions, began selling a 5 G smartphone that, after being dismantled by analysts, appeared to contain unexpectedly advanced Chinese-made silicon (albeit not quite cutting-edge).

Xi's laws of robotics

That still leaves obstacles closer to home. China's government has taken a keen interest in the regulation of AI , moving faster than most other countries. This has yet to cause too much consternation among the country's tech executives. Regulators recognise the commercial value of AI and want companies to make money from it, says one executive. They also grasp the importance of allowing Chinese companies to compete at the global level, the person says. The approval of the first batch of bots was quicker than some had feared. Long delays to product launches, such as those for new video games, often hurt the share prices of their Chinese makers.

Yet many AI enthusiasts still find some rules onerous, especially for a nascent industry. Companies offering generative- AI services are required to identify and report “illegal content”. They must also adhere to China's “core socialist values”, a sweeping and ambiguous command. After netizens spotted that a prompt for a “patriotic cat” in Ernie's drawing application produced a picture of a feline with an American flag, the words “patriotism” and “patriotic cat” were blocked in the tool. Users may be put off by what Chinese AI cannot say, or fearful of being reported for asking the wrong questions. The costs of censorship and compliance will start to add up for Baidu and other companies, warns Kai Wang of Morningstar, a research firm.

Recent experience has made it clear to China's tech executives that they operate at the pleasure of the government, and that its favour can be quickly withdrawn. Internet companies were hit with several regulatory crackdowns between 2020 and 2022. Another such assault on AI could do great damage to the firms that have invested in the technology, Baidu foremost among them. The company is testing the waters in a difficult environment. For that reason it is important to watch what Ernie says—and all that it doesn't. ■

; Sun, 03 Sep 2023 16:07:57 GMT /内容/vktp0hmf1lkgbov31vejefga2bhd5bsl https://www.economist.com/business/2023/09/03/meet-ernie-chinas-answer-to-chatgpt From social-media stars to the Mexican army, everyone wants to run an airline

T here are two measures of the recovery of the airline industry to its pre-covid altitude. First, data show that the 1.1bn seats on sale worldwide in July and August were only a whisker below levels in 2019. Seasoned observers point to a second, more subjective gauge: a slew of announcements of new or resurrected airlines with unlikely owners, dubious business models or questionably niche routes. Entrepreneurs are again being drawn to an industry that has long offered the glamour and excitement that a moth sees in a flame.

One route skyward is to apply a fresh lick of paint to a defunct brand. On August 20th Monarch Airlines, a British carrier that went bust in 2017, said it would resume carrying passengers in 2024, though details of its plans are sparse. The government of Ghana, whose flag carrier collapsed in 2010, is also relaunching a national airline. It is doing so in partnership with Ashanti Airlines, a firm scarcely accustomed to running such a service in a continent whose carriers have lost a daunting $3.5bn between them in the past three years.

In an industry where most firms struggle to a make a profit, new entrants with managers boasting a proven record might have an advantage. Yet Mexico's government recently announced that Mexicana, another carrier that went bust in 2010, will restart services later this year—under the management of Mexico's army, an organisation with little experience in the field save for operating an air force. Global Airlines, founded by James Asquith, a British social-media influencer and former banker, recently bought four second-hand a 380 superjumbos at bargain prices, promising to make transatlantic passengers “feel like a million dollars”, even in economy class. It may struggle: used a 380s are in plentiful supply because other airlines prefer newer, smaller long-haul jets, which are cheaper to run.

Other ventures operating niche routes may be equally hard to sustain. Bermudair will this month begin business-class-only flights between its island home and the United States. Later this year Beond intends to kick off a rapid expansion by taking passengers between its base in the Maldives and Dubai and Delhi, with a “private jet” experience on refitted narrow-bodied planes. Several airlines have tried over the years to run business-class-only services. Only La Compagnie, which flies between America, Europe and the Caribbean, has survived.

Red Way, a startup based in Lincoln, Nebraska, may serve as a warning. It launched in June employing the novel but misguided idea of handling marketing, ticket sales and baggage checking while outsourcing the flying to a charter airline. It ceased operations on August 31st. In June iata , an industry body based in Switzerland, doubled its forecast for net profits for the world's airlines in 2023 to $9.8bn. But, it notes, this is equivalent to $2.20 per passenger, or half a cup of coffee in Geneva. For new airlines it is a question of whether that cup is half full or half empty. ■

; Thu, 31 Aug 2023 13:03:12 GMT /内容/321r6hqkd2rlr5q2h8djpk5tg611mmia https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/31/from-social-media-stars-to-the-mexican-army-everyone-wants-to-run-an-airline India’s scandal-hit Adani Group forges on

O nly seven months ago the Adani Group, India's most valuable conglomerate at the time, looked as if it might topple. The multinational, which has interests in everything from rice to renewable energy, was accused of fraud, insider trading and fragile financing by Hindenburg Research, a New York-based short-selling firm. Though the group denied any wrongdoing, the valuation of Adani's companies fell from over $200bn to under $100bn.

The Hindenburg affair is far from over. On August 31st, as India's Supreme Court was poring over an official investigation into the claims, a report by the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project, an international consortium of journalists, made new accusations of share-trading manipulation and reporting violations (which the group also denies). Yet even as the scandal drags on, the group seems to have found its feet. Share prices have stabilised. Earnings are up. Its buoyancy reflects the premium placed on any company that can keep building in a country where that can be all but impossible.

The Hindenburg report and its aftermath have embarrassed not only the Adani Group but India. Following the report's publication in January the Supreme Court ordered the Securities and Exchange Board of India ( SEBI ), a market regulator, to investigate its allegations. After its deadline was extended, SEBI filed a largely complete report to the court on August 25th. Reuters reported that SEBI had examined 13 transactions and uncovered violations, albeit “technical” ones, that could result in fines. But a hearing due on August 29th was postponed. The sluggish official response has fed suspicions that the Adani Group's dirty laundry will not be fully aired.

Investors were also perturbed on August 12th when Deloitte resigned as auditor of one of the Adani Group companies. The accounting giant said it lacked sufficient information about the Hindenburg allegations and that the Adani company had refused to hire an independent external examiner to investigate the matter (the Adani Group's audit committee said such an examination was not needed). Share prices for the group's companies tumbled again.

This time, however, they quickly recovered. Their rebound reflects two changes since earlier this year. First, a hole in the group's finances has been filled. The Adani family, which owns the majority of each of the group's companies, had borrowed using shares as collateral. As share prices declined, there loomed the possibility of margin calls that would need to be met with funds from further share sales, triggering a downward spiral. The family has since staved off this risk by making several large share sales, with the funds presumably used to repay loans. On March 3rd GQG , a Florida-based fund-management company, bought $1.9bn of shares from the Adani family office, the first of three critical transactions that brought GQG ’s investment in the group to over $3bn.

GQG estimates that it has already made a return of more than 60% on its bet. That reflects the second change in the Adani Group's fortunes: its companies are on a winning streak. The group's net income in the year to March was $3bn, up by nearly 50%, year on year. Income in the first quarter was up by two-thirds compared with the previous quarter. The group has altered its strategy to steer away from big, risky new areas. A multi-billion-dollar petrochemical project that would have pitted Adani against Reliance, another vast conglomerate with deep pockets, was postponed. Meanwhile the Adani Group has completed some big projects: a thermal-energy plant in Jharkhand, a solar facility in Rajasthan and more. A $100bn capital budget is earmarked for the next decade.

The question is whether all this is enough for investors to overlook the continuing stream of accusations against the group. One key investor, at least, is unperturbed. “Who wants to drive a car looking at [the] rear-view mirror? Markets look forward,” says Rajiv Jain, chairman of GQG . As for the latest claims that the Adani family's holdings may have been higher than understood: “We like more insider ownership—higher the better.” Though the Hindenburg scandal refuses to go away, the Adani Group refuses to stop building. ■

N ot many companies whose profits have in essence flatlined over the past decade have seen their share price more than triple. By that measure Fujitec, a Japanese lift manufacturer, is a rare beast. The reason for its bull run is not past performance, but a growing expectation of change through investor activism, once anathema to Asian boardrooms. The company has faced a years-long campaign from activist investors, which led to the dismissal of three board members earlier this year. This was soon followed by the replacement of Fujitec's chairman, the son of the firm's founder.

Shaking up elderly, conservative and family-dominated firms in parts of Asia is getting easier. The number of companies subjected to activist demands across the region has risen markedly in recent years, from 102 in 2017 to 188 last year and 167 in only the first half of 2023, according to Diligent Market Intelligence, a research firm. That has raised Asia's share of the global total from 10% to 23%, overtaking Europe (see chart 1). In the past decade a wave of shareholder-friendly rulemaking has swept the region, and a new class of Asian activist investors is emerging.

The opportunities are enormous. Stock valuations across the region are often low, particularly for middling companies outside the gaze of international investors. Management in hock to employees, related companies, founding families or government interests are found across Asia. Vast cash piles have been generated too. The non-financial companies in the Asia-Pacific region worth more than $10bn sit on $1.94trn in cash, over 50% more than they did five years ago. Cash-rich firms with entrenched management and low valuations are ripe for a shake-up.

Fujitec has been a star example of the benefits of upturning the existing management. The company's board has been harried by Oasis Management, a Hong Kong-based activist fund which has publicly pushed for changes in capital allocation and higher payouts to shareholders, among other things, for three years. Changes to the way Japanese listed companies are run, through revised codes on stewardship and corporate governance, have made the country a new centre of investor activism. Though changes were initially pursued by Abe Shinzo, Japan's prime minister in 2012-20, investors say the appetite for corporate shake-ups is undimmed within the Japanese bureaucracy.

Asian activism has expanded beyond Japan. In the first half of the year, South Korean companies experienced the third-highest number of activist campaigns of any country in the world, jumping from fifth place globally last year and seventh in 2021. Investors have long complained about a so-called Korea discount, with inexpensive stocks littering the market. Last year a fierce battle broke out for control of SM Entertainment, a listed K -pop production firm, when Align Partners, a boutique investment firm which had taken a 1% stake in the company, began an ultimately successful campaign to terminate sm Entertainment's cosy relationship with its founder, Lee Soo-man.

Two factors are driving the Korean trend. The first came after a spate of scandals in 2015, when the South Korean government had made a concerted effort to halt an activist campaign by Elliott Investment Management, a Florida-based activist fund, against Samsung, a national champion. The turmoil that followed led to a jail term for Hong Wan-sun, a former head of the asset-management division of the country's National Pension Service ( nps ). A stewardship code designed to stop asset managers cosying up to corporate interests has since been introduced.

The second factor is a boom in retail investing in South Korea during the covid-19 pandemic. The number of active stock-trading accounts surged from 29m in 2019 to 50m two years later, adding millions of voters with new concerns about how companies are managed.

The role of the NPS illustrates a common theme across the region. The fund owns around $108bn in South Korean stocks, making it a whale. In other markets, large investors with political and government-linked roles wield huge influence. China has a range of state-aligned funds, pursuing a variety of goals for the central and local governments. In Thailand the king personally owns large shares of the big listed companies. All have the potential to fuel or frustrate shareholder campaigns, owing to their sheer size.

Chairmen of the bored

That helps to explain why activism is far more difficult elsewhere in the region. Despite the proliferation of seemingly shareholder-friendly codes for corporate stewardship over the past decade, the reality of governance is hugely varied. Hong Kong, India, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand have instituted their own stewardship codes, but the seemingly widespread support for greater shareholder involvement is illusory, according to Gen Goto, Alan K. Koh and Dan W. Puchniak, respectively of the University of Tokyo, Nanyang Technological University and Singapore Management University. They note that the codes are not truly designed to disrupt the status quo, and lack the legal weight to do so.

What's more, the structure of the region's markets varies wildly. In much of Asia, corporate ownership is highly concentrated, and a wide range of influential and politically aligned investors make things more difficult. In 2020 the largest three owners held 62% of the average stock in Hong Kong and Singapore, and as much as 72% in Indonesia. The equivalent figures in Japan and South Korea were 41% and 48% respectively (see chart 2).

Most countries in Asia have yet to unlock even a fraction of the potential of greater activism. India is still a relative black hole for investor campaigns, with a single-digit number of activist proposals counted by Diligent Market Intelligence each year. Invesco, an American investment firm, sold the stake it had accumulated in Zee Entertainment Enterprises, an Indian media company, earlier this year after a failed activist campaign. In China, investors have occasionally succeeded in winning reforms from companies when there is no obvious threat to the government's influence over the corporate landscape. But the variety of state investors and politically sensitive targets makes a robust and lively system of activism difficult to imagine, particularly where foreign investors are concerned.

Yet even with the limits on changes to corporate stewardship, some activists have achieved success in concentrated markets. Singapore had seven activist campaigns during the first half of this year, including a battle between Quarz Capital, an activist fund, and the board of Sabana REIT , an industrial-property trust. Quarz has campaigned to internalise the management of the properties, in line with the American model in which the trust takes responsibility for management rather than contracting it out. On August 7th Sabana's unit holders backed the campaign in an extraordinary general meeting, a first for Singapore's property industry.

Asia is still in the foothills of the opportunities that activists might eventually find, if the influential actors that dominate the markets are disempowered. The circumstances of concentrated shareholder power and the lack of investor engagement in different markets are as varied as the number of jurisdictions. But the shared attributes of thousands of companies across the region—juicy cash balances and sleepy management—mean the pickings are rich, if activists can reach them. ■

; Thu, 31 Aug 2023 13:03:12 GMT /内容/a5uva2jg4hb8mbg25oj05nu5rbpag6v1 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/31/the-rise-of-the-asian-activist-investor The best bosses know how to subtract work

C ompanies are used to celebrating addition. Profits, customers and share prices should go up rather than fall. Innovation is the adding of new products. Larger numbers are a measure of career success: managers climb the corporate ladder by taking on more reports, running heftier budgets and trousering bigger salaries. Genuine superstars don't just add. They multiply. The best software programmers are tagged as “10x developers”, for supposedly being ten times more productive than their peers.

Firms are not always opposed to subtraction. There are good kinds of cuts: carbon emissions, most obviously. Reducing costs is a necessary part of management, though not a welcome one. But the value of doing less is underestimated. The best bosses are those who take things away as well as add them on.

That means clearing time for employees to get work done. Meetings are almost always called by bosses. Some are useful; many of them have all the pizzazz and impact of a speed-awareness course. Shopify, an e-commerce firm, began the year by deleting 12,000 recurring meetings from corporate calendars, and asking everyone to think carefully before reinstating them. The company reports a rise in productivity as a result of the cull.

The only thing worse than having too many meetings is not being invited to them at all. So whenever meetings do take place, surprisingly large numbers of people can turn up. Minus-minded managers will give employees permission not to attend if they are not needed.

By the same token, good bosses will send messages when necessary, not every time a bright idea pops into their head. They will reduce the tempo of work, by leaving employees time to concentrate. They will be clear if something is urgent or not. A recent study by Laura Giurge of London Business School and Vanessa Bohns of Cornell University found that receivers of an email routinely overestimate how quickly its sender expects a reply.

Subtraction is not just about removing day-to-day distractions. It's also about taking decisions to kill off projects and products that are going nowhere, and to focus efforts on the most important bits of the business. Peter Drucker, the doyen of management theorists, was an advocate of “planned abandonment”, so that resources that are tied up in marginal activities are freed for more profitable use. Executives should, he advised, routinely ask the same question of every aspect of the business: “If we did not do this already, would we go into it now knowing what we now know?”

In “The Case for Good Jobs”, a new book, Zeynep Ton of MIT Sloan School of Management argues that doing less can often make commercial sense. Costco, a well-regarded American retailer that believes in the “intelligent loss of sales”, has a deliberately limited product range. That means it can focus its buying power more effectively, forecast demand more accurately and use its employees' time more productively.

Less may not sound like a great outcome for customers, but at some point choice is deeply wearying. When you have spent more time trying to decide what to watch on a streaming service than it takes to go to the cinema and watch “Oppenheimer” twice, scarcity seems pretty attractive.

Doing and offering less goes against the grain in many ways. One is how humans are wired. Professor Ton cites a study, published in Nature in 2021 by Gabrielle Adams of the University of Virginia and her co-authors, in which people were asked to think of ways to improve something (like the design of a miniature-golf hole) or solve a problem (such as making the pattern on a grid symmetrical). The researchers found that, without an explicit prompt to think about subtraction, participants systematically defaulted to adding features rather than taking them away.

There are plenty of other hurdles to embracing the minus mindset. The “sunk-cost fallacy” means that managers find it hard to abandon projects that have already soaked up money. Firms are often scared to give up optionality: what if this tiddly new venture turns into the next big thing? Sending emails and filling the calendar is a way to feel busy even if not much of value is getting done.

Recruitment processes and performance reviews reinforce the importance of additive activity; it is unusual for a job candidate to brag about the things they didn't achieve. But getting rid of work ought to be a vital part of the managers' toolkit. Add value. Do less. ■
